head.title: The Politics of Oil, Then and Now

hedline.hl1: The Politics of Oil, Then and Now

abstract.p: Ezra Field letter holds tapping our strategic oil reserves will likely have a counterproductive effect

block.p: Re ''Clinton Approves Releasing Some Oil From U.S. Reserve'' (front page, Sept. 23):

Tapping our strategic oil reserves will likely have a counterproductive effect. Adding 30 million barrels of oil to the global market will have an insignificant effect on total supply, while any subsequent effort to replenish our strategic reserves will only send prices even higher by increasing the demand for oil.
Re ''Clinton Approves Releasing Some Oil From U.S. Reserve'' (front page, Sept. 23):

Tapping our strategic oil reserves will likely have a counterproductive effect. Adding 30 million barrels of oil to the global market will have an insignificant effect on total supply, while any subsequent effort to replenish our strategic reserves will only send prices even higher by increasing the demand for oil.

Tapping our reserves will send the wrong message to the OPEC countries. It is a further sign of Western political weakness in the face of rising oil prices. And federal intervention in the oil market will set a dangerous precedent for the future, potentially turning any commodity-price volatility into a political issue.
